awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Open Infrastructure to Reduce Burden on Researchers and Federal Agencies
awd_abstract_narration:
Johns Hopkins University, in partnership with six other institutions, proposes to design a set of recommendations, use cases, specifications, and workflows that will transform the deposit of manuscripts into federal agency repositories, thereby reducing burden on researchers, universities, and federal agencies. This early exploratory research undertakes to develop solutions for issues that arise when projects are multi-institution, federal agency workflows are vastly different, and the integrity of information is critical. As research becomes increasingly convergent, there is a major risk of an increasingly complex environment for investigators, universities, and funding agencies. By binding grants or award data to primary research objects such as articles, data, or software, the proposed research represents an important step toward data analytics on researcher and university productivity and collaboration. The proposed work has the potential to positively impact every university that receives federal funding and every federal funding agency with a public access compliance policy.

An early implementation of the PI's Public Access Submission System (PASS) system has been shown to work with the NIH PubMed Central.  But scaling beyond PubMedCentral requires exploratory research such as to establish the logic for simultaneous submission of a publication to multiple federal grant repositories and institution repositories.   Research questions include how a third-party applications such as the PASS system, manage cross-institutional grants data, identities, and deposit workflows.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Vaccine development during Covid-19 demonstrated the essential value of public access to articles, data, and software generated by university researchers from federally funding research. This project developed mechanisms for reducing effort on researchers and for interfacing university repositories and systems with their federal counterpart systems for greater public access to research outputs.

One of the key outcomes from this project was a specification for packaging or encapsulating content (and information about linkages between different types of content) based on a well-established community standard and informed by community feedback. Multiple university partners and federal agency observers participated in a workshop and provided important feedback toward the specification. Furthermore, the project team also met with key individuals from NSF's Public Access Repository (PAR) team for further information. 

Johns Hopkins University in partnership with Harvard University and MIT developed the Public Access Submission System (PASS), a university-based application that conforms to the packaging specification. PASS already integrates with NIH's PubMedCentral, which provides pubilc access to articles based on grants from nine federal funding agencies. While PASS represents an exemplar, the packaging specification is general enough that additional third party applciations could be developed. 

In addition to the specification, another key outcome from this project is the adoption of PASS as an official product of the Eclipse Foundation, a well-known open source membership organization. Working with the Eclipse Foundation handbook, PASS is being updated from both a design and engineering perspective into a more robust, scable application such that multiple universities and federal agencies could use it and further develop it. In addition to this engineering work, the Eclipse Foundation is providing expertise toward a sustainable model for PASS including business plan development and marketing support. 

While work remains to integrate PASS (and other applications) with NSF's PAR system, the outcomes from this project represent important, foundational results from which to build upon for subsequent development, both by universities and federal funding agencies. 


Last Modified: 02/27/2022
Modified by: Golam S Choudhury
